item.title: Russia Says It Will Rejoin Deal Allowing Ukrainian Grain Shipments
item.description: Moscow announced that it was resuming its participation in an international agreement aimed at helping countries facing acute food shortages.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier looking into the hull of a damaged Russian armored vehicle in the Kharkiv region on Tuesday.

item.title: Netanyahu Extends Lead in Israel Election, Projections Say
item.description: If the right-wing bloc does cement an election victory, Benjamin Netanyahu, Israel’s longest-serving prime minister, will return to office even as he stands trial on corruption charges.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Benjamin Netanyahu, right, in Jerusalem on Tuesday. With about two thirds of the vote counted, Israel’s three main broadcasters were projecting that Mr. Netanyahu’s party, Likud, would finish first.

item.title: Power Outages Leave Kyiv, Ukraine, Draped in Darkness
item.description: The streets of Ukraine’s capital, illuminated with nightlife only weeks ago, are shrouded in darkness and shadows now because of restrictions on the use of electricity. The lack of light creates moments of apprehension, but also of beauty.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Brendan Hoffman
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times

item.title: Bolsonaro Agrees to Transition, Two Days After Losing Brazil Election
item.description: Breaking his silence, President Jair Bolsonaro did not admit defeat or repeat his baseless claims about election fraud, but his administration signaled that the transfer of power would proceed.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and André Spigariol
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil arriving for a news conference at the Alvorada Palace along with his ministers on Tuesday in Brasilia, the capital.

item.title: After Covid Lockdown, Fear and Unrest Sweep iPhone Factory in China
item.description: Hundreds of workers are said to have fled, afraid of being forced into quarantine with inadequate food and supplies.
item.dc:creator: Chang Che and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:credit: Hangpai Xingyang, via Associated Press
item.media:description: People leaving a Foxconn compound in Zhengzhou, China, on Saturday.

item.title: Denmark’s Center-Left Coalition Wins Election Majority
item.description: An unpredictable race ultimately gave the governing Social Democratic Party its best showing in two decades, though analysts said it looked set to form a more centrist government.
item.dc:creator: Jasmina Nielsen and Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Martin Sylvest/Ritzau Scanpix, via Reuters
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen said she wanted a “broad government,” reaching across the political spectrum.

item.title: North Korea Launches 23 Missiles, Triggering Air-Raid Alarm in South
item.description: People on an island took cover as one missile landed near South Korean territorial waters. The South responded by firing three missiles of its own.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Jung Yeon-Je/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A TV screen in Seoul showed news footage from Ulleung, a South Korean island where residents took cover after North Korea fired a missile into nearby waters on Wednesday.

item.title: Pleas for Help Went Unheeded for Hours in Deadly South Korea Crush
item.description: Transcripts of desperate emergency calls exposed the failure of the government response, and contradicted official claims about when the disaster was first reported.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Yonhap, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The national police chief, Yoon Hee-keun, acknowledged Monday that his agency’s handling of 112 emergency calls was “inappropriate.”

item.title: Canada Aims to Add 1.45 Million Immigrants by 2025
item.description: The policy would increase immigration one week after the country’s census agency announced that Canada had set a new milestone in immigration.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: An increasing number of Canadians are immigrants or the children of immigrants.

item.title: Colombia’s President Visits Venezuela, Moving Away From Isolation
item.description: Colombia’s new president met with his Venezuelan counterpart, a milestone in the move by leftist leaders in Latin America to ease the isolation of Nicolás Maduro’s government in Caracas.
item.dc:creator: Isayen Herrera and Julie Turkewitz
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Gustavo Petro of Colombia with President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela on Tuesday in Caracas.

item.title: India Bridge Offered Respite to Migrants, Before Taking Their Lives
item.description: Cash compensation for victims’ families will do little to make up for the life, and economic hope, of migrants among the 134 killed in India.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir and Emily Schmall
item.media:credit: Ajit Solanki/Associated Press
item.media:description: Watching search operations on Tuesday on the Machchhu River in Morbi, India, two days after a bridge there collapsed and plunged hundreds of people into the water.

item.title: Matt Hancock, Former UK Health Secretary, Gets a TV Gig, Then a Suspension
item.description: Matt Hancock, who was filmed in a steamy embrace with an aide, breaking strict Covid distancing rules, will appear on “I’m a Celebrity … Get Me Out of Here!”
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.category: I'm a Celebrity...Get Me Out of Here! (TV Program)
item.media:credit: Hollie Adams/Getty Images
item.media:description: Matt Hancock last month in London. His decision to appear on a reality TV show has prompted anger and mockery.

item.title: Under Russia’s Rain of Fire in Kherson, Ukrainians Sneak Forward
item.description: The commander of a Ukrainian reconnaissance unit spearheading the counterattack in the southern region of Kherson explained how his team helped breach defenses he described as frighteningly dense.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall and Ivor Prickett
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times

item.title: Key Evidence in Report on Missing Mexican Students Cannot Be Verified, Experts Say
item.description: An international panel said it had found numerous inconsistencies in evidence presented by the government’s truth commission on the disappearance of the 43 students in 2014.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff and Oscar Lopez
item.media:credit: Luis Antonio Rojas for The New York Times
item.media:description: The faces of the 43 missing students have become part of the cityscape of Mexico City.

item.title: Kyiv Prepares 425 Shelters in Case of a Russian Nuclear Attack
item.description: Worries that the Kremlin might turn to its nuclear arsenal have deepened since President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia raised the specter of using such weapons to hold on to territorial gains.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: The basement of a cafe that doubles as a bomb shelter last month in Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital.

item.title: The New Abortion Landscape
item.description: Women in states with abortion bans are turning to telemedicine.
item.dc:creator: Emily Bazelon
item.media:credit: George Frey/Reuters
item.media:description: Misoprostol is used to terminate early pregnancies.

item.title: Hurricane or Typhoon? How Tropical Cyclones Get Their Names.
item.description: There are variations around the world, particularly in the Western Pacific, in how countries name and measure tropical cyclones. We can explain.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Nhac Nguyen/Agence France-Presse/Getty Images
item.media:description: A man walking along the beach after Typhoon Noru passed Da Nang, Vietnam, in September.

item.title: As Climate Change Worsens, US Weighs Which Communities to Save
item.description: Native American tribes are competing for the first federal grants designed to help relocate communities away from dangers posed by global warming.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Flavelle and Tailyr Irvine
item.media:credit: Tailyr Irvine for The New York Times

item.title: Trial of Kansas Teacher Who Joined ISIS Shows Family’s Deep Scars
item.description: Allison Fluke-Ekren, a teacher from Kansas, dragged her family to Syria and forced her daughter, Leyla, to train for war on behalf of the Islamic State. Now her daughter wields final words against her.
item.dc:creator: Adam Goldman
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Photo illustration by Leslie dela Vega/The New York Times; photographs from clockwise from top left: Ahmed Mardnli/EPA, via Shutterstock; Alexandria Sheriff’s Office, via Associated Press; Associated Press
item.media:description: Allison Fluke-Ekren, center, a Muslim convert from Kansas, and, right, pictured with her second husband, Volkan Ekren, and their children. The children’s faces have been blacked out to protect their identities.

item.title: Russia rejoins the grain deal after saying it received safety assurances.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and James C. McKinley Jr.
item.media:credit: Umit Bektas/Reuters
item.media:description: Commercial vessels that are part of the Black Sea grain deal waiting to pass through the Bosporus in Turkey on Monday.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: The latest developments from elections in Brazil, Denmark and Israel.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil arriving for a news conference at the Alvorada Palace along with his ministers on Tuesday in Brasilia, the capital.

item.title: Netanyahu Holds Slight Lead in Israeli Election, Exit Polls Show
item.description: If the right-wing bloc does eke out a narrow victory, it will allow Mr. Netanyahu, Israel’s longest-serving prime minister, to return to office even as he stands trial on corruption charges.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of former Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu celebrating at Likud’s headquarters in Jerusalem on Tuesday.

item.title: Russia Pushes Ukrainians to Relocate as Possible Battle for Kherson Looms
item.description: Ukrainian officials said that Moscow was trying to clear out civilians to provide places for newly mobilized Russian troops to occupy.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Alexander Ermochenko/Reuters
item.media:description: Boarding a ferry during the evacuation of the city of Kherson, Ukraine, on Monday.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Israel Votes, Again
item.description: Plus Bolsonaro will step aside in Brazil and investigations mount in India’s bridge collapse.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Voting during Israel’s parliamentary election at a polling station in Bnei Brak, Israel, on Tuesday.

item.title: For Netanyahu’s Corruption Trial, Court Is Hearing From Over 300 Witnesses
item.description: The Israeli electorate remains divided over the former prime minister, even as his continuing trial on corruption charges has mostly dropped out of the headlines.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: The corruption trial of former Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has barely figured in the current election campaign.

item.title: On the scene of a Russian rocket attack.
Scientists Are Gaining On RSV, a Persistent Threat to Children
item.description: Vaccines and treatments are in trials, but the virus remains a leading killer of infants worldwide.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: Marijan Murat/Picture Alliance, via Getty Images
item.media:description: An intensive care nurse caring for a child suffering from respiratory syncytial virus in Stuttgart, Germany, last year.

item.title: What’s the Future of Affirmative Action?
item.description: The Supreme Court seems poised to end the policy.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Shuran Huang for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Supreme Court yesterday morning.

item.title: Denmark Heads for Period of Uncertainty After Snap Election
item.description: With no clear coalition as of Tuesday night, the stage is set for a negotiation to form what analysts say will likely be a centrist government.
item.dc:creator: Jasmina Nielsen and Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Jonathan Nackstrand/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Campaign posters in Copenhagen last month. In a crowded field of more than a dozen parties — including some newcomers — analysts said that the election could throw up some surprises.

item.title: Why Does Israel Keep Having So Many Elections?
item.description: A divided electorate and shifting alliances make for a delicate balance in the country’s voting outcomes and lawmakers’ ability to hold diverse blocs together.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Voting during Israel’s parliamentary election at a polling station in Bnei Brak, Israel, on Tuesday.

item.title: Israel Election: Here’s what’s at stake.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Voting in Migdal Haemek, Israel, on Tuesday.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Skyrocketing inflation in Europe.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Relentless inflation is complicating policymakers’ efforts to steer economies through a difficult winter.

item.title: Three more grain ships set sail from Ukraine amid questions about their safety.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky, Anton Troianovski and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Ozan Kose/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A cargo ship loaded with grain being inspected in the southern entrance to the Bosporus near Istanbul on Monday.

item.title: Russian Missiles Deliver New Woe to Kyiv, Knocking Out Tap Water
item.description: Moscow kept up its campaign to destroy civilian infrastructure, in an apparent bid — so far unsuccessful — to break Ukrainian morale by making cities unlivable.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Collecting drinking water from public taps in Shevchenko Park on Monday in Kyiv.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Jair Bolsonaro Loses
item.description: But he has not conceded Brazil’s presidential election.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of President Jair Bolsonaro watched in Brasília, Brazil, as the results of the country’s presidential election were announced on Sunday.

item.title: Rishi Sunak’s First Crisis: Turmoil Engulfing His Home Secretary
item.description: Suella Braverman has come under political fire for breaching security rules and for her handling of immigration issues.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Hannah Mckay/Reuters
item.media:description: Suella Braverman, Britain’s home secretary, leaving 10 Downing Street in London last week.

item.title: Sea Drone Attack on Russian Fleet Puts Focus on Expanded Ukrainian Arms
item.description: Military experts say that the apparent use of remote-controlled boats to attack Russian ships over the weekend is likely to demonstrate a new capability for Ukrainian forces.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:credit: Maxim Shemetov/Reuters
item.media:description: The Black Sea seen from Cape Fiolent, outside the Crimean port city of Sevastopol in 2018.

item.title: South Korea Halloween Deaths Were ‘Absolutely Avoidable’ Disaster, Experts Say
item.description: Days after the deaths of more than 150 young people, officials were still struggling to explain what exactly went wrong and who was to blame.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Mourners on Monday gathered at a makeshift memorial to the victims of a crowd crush in Seoul on Saturday night.

item.title: Oleg Tinkov Renounces Russian Citizenship Over Ukraine
item.description: The multimillionaire said on Instagram that he “can’t and won’t be associated with a fascist country.”
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Maxim Shemetov/Reuters
item.media:description: Russian business tycoon Oleg Tinkov in 2019.

item.title: What Lula’s Victory in Brazil Means for Climate
item.description: The president-elect once helped slash deforestation rates in the Amazon rainforest. He says he wants to do it again.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Andreoni
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, now president-elect, at a campaign rally on Saturday.

item.title: Aging Infrastructure May Create Higher Flood Risk in L.A., Study Finds
item.description: Between 197,000 and 874,000 city residents could experience a foot of flooding during an extreme storm, scientists found. Most of them don’t live in beachfront mansions.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: John Antczak/Associated Press
item.media:description: Water raced down the Los Angeles River in February 2019 as a powerful storm drenched California.

item.title: Kyiv Residents Line Up At Wells After City Loses Running Water
item.description: Before the latest round of assaults on Ukrainian infrastructure, a buzz had returned to the capital.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: People collect drinking water from public taps in Shevchenko Park in Kyiv on Monday after Russia’s missile attacks.

item.title: At Least 134 Dead With Yet Another Failure in India’s Infrastructure
item.description: After the deaths of at least 134 pedestrians, the country is asking why its infrastructure has failed so calamitously once again.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir, Suhasini Raj, Hari Kumar and Emily Schmall
item.media:credit: Ajit Solanki/Associated Press
item.media:description: Rescuers on Monday continued to search the Machchhu River in Morbi, India. The bridge that collapsed had recently reopened after seven months of repairs.

item.title: What Is COP27?
item.description: With the world still struggling to get global warming under control, diplomats will gather in Egypt for United Nations climate talks. Here are some key facts.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

item.title: Bolsonaro Is Silent After Brazil Election Defeat
item.description: President Jair Bolsonaro has not yet recognized his election defeat after months of warning, without evidence, that opponents would rig the vote.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas, Flávia Milhorance and André Spigariol
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of President Jair Bolsonaro watching in Brasília, the capital of Brazil, as the results of the presidential election were announced on Sunday.

item.title: As Last Module Docks, China Completes Its Space Station
item.description: The Mengtian module was launched into orbit and docked with the Tiangong space station, the latest step in Beijing’s effort to surpass the United States in space exploration.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:credit: Tu Haichao/Xinhua, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The Mengtian module, with the Long March rocket that would take it into orbit, at China’s launch site in Hainan Province last week.

item.title: Russian Missile Debris Lands in Moldova
item.description: Parts of a Russian missile intercepted by Ukrainian air defenses landed in a Moldovan border village on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova and Monika Pronczuk

item.title: More Equitable Justice
item.description: Racial disparities in incarceration have fallen.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Michelle Gustafson for The New York Times
item.media:description: District Attorney Larry Krasner in July, when the homicide rate in Philadelphia had reached a rate of 300.

item.title: Glimpses of Life with the Sea Clown Sailing Circus Troupe
item.description: A photographer embedded with the Sea Clown Sailing Circus on the troupe’s journeys through the Mediterranean. Here’s what he saw.
item.dc:creator: Nicola Zolin

item.title: Cholera Outbreaks Surge Worldwide As Vaccine Supply Drains
item.description: A record number of outbreaks have been reported after droughts, floods and wars have forced large numbers of people to live in unsanitary conditions.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen
item.media:credit: Ricardo Arduengo/Reuters
item.media:description: Patients being treated for cholera at the Gheskio Center Hospital in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, this month.

item.title: He’s an Outspoken Defender of Meat. Industry Funds His Research, Files Show.
item.description: A UC Davis professor runs an academic center that was conceived by a trade group, according to records, and gets most of its funding from farming interests.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:credit: Allison V. Smith for The New York Times
item.media:description: Critics say close financial ties between the Clear Center at UC Davis and the industry it studies create the potential for conflict of interest.

item.title: South Korea Mourns Loss of Young Victims, and Their Dreams, in Halloween Crowd Crush
item.description: More than 100 of those killed in the South Korean capital were in their 20s, planning for the next chapter of their lives.
item.dc:creator: Su-Hyun Lee, John Yoon, Luke Vander Ploeg and Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial in the Itaewon neighborhood of Seoul on Monday in honor of the victims of the Halloween disaster.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: A devastating tragedy in Seoul.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: A policeman guards the alley, barely 11 feet wide, in Seoul’s Itaewon neighborhood, where more than 150 people died.

item.title: Brazil Ejects Bolsonaro and Brings Back Leftist Former Leader Lula
item.description: Brazilians voted out their far-right leader, Jair Bolsonaro, after a single term and replaced him with former President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, the leftist candidate who was elected president, on the way to vote in São Bernardo do Campo, Brazil, on Sunday.

item.title: Will Bolsonaro Dispute the Results of Brazil’s Presidential Election?
item.description: He ha
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Flávia Milhorance
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of President Jair Bolsonaro reacting as Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva took the lead in the election on Sunday night in Brasília.

item.title: Russia Is Urged to Rejoin Grain Deal as Hunger Warnings Mount
item.description: Moscow dismissed accusations that it was using food as a weapon and said Ukraine was to blame for its decision to suspend an agreement that allowed for grain shipments.
item.dc:creator: Shashank Bengali, Abdi Latif Dahir and Natalie Kitroeff
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: A cargo vessel laden with grain destined for Ethiopia prepared to set off in August from Port Pivdennyi in Ukraine.
